title-group.article-title: Book Review: Medical Muses: Hysteria in Nineteenth-Century Paris

contrib.aff: Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, Nebraska.

article-meta.product: Hustvedt A. Medical Muses: Hysteria in Nineteenth-Century Paris. New York, NY: Norton; 2011. pp. $26.95. ISBN 978-0-393-02560-6.

body.p: In late 2011, a group of teenage girls in Le Roy, New York, exhibited apparently involuntary movements and vocalizations that resembled the tics of Tourette syndrome.1 –3 The news media promptly promoted this into a major story and many “talking heads” developed wild and often sinister theories of the origin of this “epidemic.”1,2 In the end, however, this episode was a good example of hysteria—a condition that was so famously characterized by Jean-Martin Charcot at the Salpêtrière Hospital in Paris, France in the 1870s. Coincidentally in the same year as Le Roy “epidemic,” a book appeared detailing the history of the Parisian hysterics. This extensively researched text written by Asti Hustvedt (who received a PhD in French literature and works as an editor and translator) provides a detailed biography of the career of Charcot and then interweaves the biographies of Charcot’s major contemporaries (Figure 1) into the detailed stories of the 3 star hysterics: Marie “Blanche” Wittmann, Louise Augustine Gleizes, and Geneviève Basile Legrand. This is a compelling tale of the development of neurology in late-19th-century Paris, which became the cradle for the burgeoning specialty. The Salpêtrière Hospital took its name from the 16th-century site used as an arsenal for gunpowder (made from saltpeter). The “hospital” was initially little more than a warehouse for female outcasts, but became famous through the efforts of the 18th-century director Philippe Pinel to reform the system and free the inmates from their chains. Charcot assumed the directorship in the 1860s and transformed this largest hospital in Europe to the mecca for neurologic training and investigation. Charcot meticulously described and characterized many disorders, some of which now bear his eponym. However, the issue of hysteria is one for which he was most known in Paris during his life and because of which he was reviled by many of his trainees and colleagues after his death.

Unlike Enquist,13 who wrote a novel concerning the French hysterics, and Showalter,14 who wrote an exposé concerning hysteria, Hustvedt, with her French language background, has been able to painstakingly find and review available and obscure original materials and provides extensive endnotes and a large bibliography to document her carefully crafted writing. This book is a must-read since the problem of hysteria (currently given the more politically correct designation of “conversion disorder”) is one that still commonly confronts neurologists (both adult and child) in their practices. In addition, the book will help place in context many of the other French neurologists whose eponyms famously appear often in neurologists’ clinical records (eg, Guillaume-Benjamin-Amand Duchenne de Boulogne of muscular dystrophy fame, Désiré-Magloire Bourneville of tuberous sclerosis complex fame, and Joseph Babinski of extensor plantar response fame).
